Introduction

Congenital clubfoot, or congenital talipes equinovarus, is characterized by a fixed, plantar-flexed, adducted, and inverted foot.  If untreated, congenital clubfoot can result in severe deformity and functional impairment.  It should be differentiated from positional clubfoot, a common newborn condition that appears similar to congenital clubfoot but in which the foot can be passively manipulated into a neutral position.

Pathogenesis



Congenital clubfoot is an idiopathic condition characterized by abnormally shaped and positioned tarsal bones (eg, talus, calcaneus).  In a developing fetus with congenital clubfoot, the tissues surrounding the tarsal bones are underdeveloped, and the muscles are shortened and contracted.  The talus is displaced medially, and the calcaneus is in a varus position under the talus (

figure 1
).  This leads to a plantar-flexed foot with an adducted and internally rotated forefoot, resembling the shape of a golf club.



Congenital clubfoot is usually an isolated condition and idiopathic, but it can be associated with neuromuscular disorders (eg, spina bifida) or genetic syndromes (eg, trisomy 18).  A relevant family history also increases the risk for congenital clubfoot.

Clinical presentation



Congenital clubfoot presents in the immediate newborn period and is characterized by 4 main components on examination (

figure 2
):



  • Forefoot adduction.
  • Midfoot cavus (high arch).
  • Hindfoot varus (heel tilts inward).
  • Hindfoot equinus (heel elevated).


The affected ankle is rigid and does not correct with passive range of motion testing.  The calf may be less muscular, and, in unilateral cases, shortened leg length is apparent on the affected side.  Bilateral congenital clubfoot is present in approximately half of cases.

Diagnosis and evaluation



Congenital clubfoot is a clinical diagnosis that is made shortly after birth based on the presence of a fixed, plantar-flexed, adducted, and inverted foot.  During routine ultrasonography in the second or third trimester, it may be diagnosed prenatally by visualization of the characteristic clubfoot shape that does not change with fetal movement.

Differential diagnosis



Congenital clubfoot is a clinical diagnosis that should be distinguished from other foot deformities, including:



  • Positional clubfoot (
    figure 3
    ):  Intra-uterine crowding causes the foot to turn inward, appearing similar to congenital clubfoot; however, the foot can be passively repositioned to midline on examination in positional clubfoot.  On prenatal ultrasonographic imaging, the foot position does not appear fixed.
  • Metatarsus adductus (
    figure 4
    ):  In utero molding of the midfoot is a cause of in-toeing and gives the foot a characteristic "C" shape.  The hindfoot is in the neutral (or valgus) position.
  • Acquired equinovarus:  Hindfoot varus and equinus may develop secondary to a neuromuscular condition such as cerebral palsy.  Increased spasticity of the lower leg muscles can result in fixed equinovarus positioning over time instead of being present at birth.

Management



Initial management of congenital clubfoot is nonsurgical and involves stretching and serial casting.  Because the anatomy is most supple in early infancy, casting is ideally initiated in the first few weeks of life.  After nonsurgical treatment is complete (ie, normal foot position can be attained), an Achilles tendon release procedure is often performed to increase range of motion.  Long-term bracing is then required until age 4-5; successful outcomes depend on adherence during the bracing period.  If the response is inadequate or if clubfoot recurs, reconstructive surgery may be considered.

Prognosis



Early and appropriate treatment of congenital clubfoot can lead to excellent functional and cosmetic results.  However, recurrence may occur, and careful follow-up is necessary.  If left untreated, congenital clubfoot can lead to weight bearing on the lateral aspects of the feet and an abnormal gait, particularly in patients with bilateral deformities.

Summary



Congenital talipes equinovarus is a clinical diagnosis characterized by a fixed, plantar-flexed, adducted, and inverted foot.  It should be differentiated from positional clubfoot, in which the foot can be easily repositioned into a natural position.  Early treatment for congenital clubfoot includes stretching and serial casting and can significantly improve the appearance and function of the affected foot.
